section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review the letters Ss, Ff, and Pp, engage children with song, and introduce the vocabulary word sketch.
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking the guiding question: What are the dog and the bird building together?
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Identify rhyming words.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify letters Ss, Ff, and Pp, and sort words by initial letter sounds.
Help children segment words into onset and rime and match rhyming word pairs.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find characters in your book?
Can you pretend to build a house?
What would you need to measure before you build a house?
Can you write a story about building something?
Can you sketch something you can build?
Can you find the letter s in the word house?
Can you use these blocks to build a house?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the shows empathy Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (plan, build).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Ready, Set, Build!
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books.
Identify rhyming words.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to identify emotions and show empathy by asking and answering the question, How do you feel?
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is the character building something in your book?
Can you pretend to help someone build something?
Can you use cubes to show some building blocks and then count them?
Can you write a story about someone helping you?
Can you make a picture that shows people helping one another?
Can you find words that start with the letter f in your book? Can you read those words?
Can you build a house for the dog and the bird from the book?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ready, Set, Build! by Meg Fleming, illustrated by Jarvis. Text copyright © 2017 by Meg Fleming. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Jarvis. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little Bee Books, an imprint of Bonnier Publishing USA. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about safety and teach vocabulary (lift).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Ready, Set, Build! and asking the guiding question: How do the dog and the bird stay safe while they are building?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify rhyming words.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children in an extended conversation about safety.
Help children make a classroom safety poster.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Do the characters in your book keep themselves safe?
Can you pretend you are building something? How will you stay safe?
Can you think of tools the dog and the bird use to measure? Can you tell me what the tools are called?
Can you write a list of classroom rules to keep children safe?
Can you use these materials to make a picture of the dog and the bird staying safe?
Can you find words that start with the letter p in your book? Can you read them?
Can you build safely? What will you build?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ready, Set, Build! by Meg Fleming, illustrated by Jarvis. Text copyright © 2017 by Meg Fleming. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Jarvis. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little Bee Books, an imprint of Bonnier Publishing USA.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: markers (nikkytok), poster board (gfdunt).

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Three Little Rabbits

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about building materials and introduce vocabulary (straw, sticks).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Ready, Set, Build! and The Three Little Rabbits.
Read closely to connect to the concept question: Why do we build things?
Offer an extended play opportunity, encouraging children to show flexibility as they explore different building materials.
Share the daily writing options.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Compare and contrast stories relating to the same topic.
Identify rhyming words.
Write for different purposes.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify words that begin with the letters Ss, Ff, and Pp.
Invite children to imagine how the story would change depending on building materials used.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which story do you like best? Why did you like it best?
Can you pretend your are one of the rabbits from today’s story? How will you build your house?
Can you sort these building blocks by size?
Can you write a story about building a house with some materials that are silly?
Can you use some of our art materials to make the three rabbits from the story?
Can you find things in your station that start with the letter s?
Can you build a tall tower? If it falls down, try a different way of building it. Can you tell me which way worked better?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ready, Set, Build! by Meg Fleming, illustrated by Jarvis. Text copyright © 2017 by Meg Fleming. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Jarvis. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little Bee Books, an imprint of Bonnier Publishing USA.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: markers (nikkytok), paper (jannoon028).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to act like a builder and introduce vocabulary (guide).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question: What steps does the dog follow to build his house?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding, focusing on what children learned about building this week.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Identify rhyming words.
Write for different purposes.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children to use fine motor skills as they independently write in response to this week’s prompt: If you could build anything, what would it be?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about building, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be a builder? What will you build?
Can you use these pattern blocks to make a house?
Can you write about the building tool you like to use best, and why you like to use it?
What materials did you enjoy using the most this week? Why?
Can you find things in your station that start with the letter p?
Why did you want to build this?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ready, Set, Build! by Meg Fleming, illustrated by Jarvis. Text copyright © 2017 by Meg Fleming. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Jarvis. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little Bee Books, an imprint of Bonnier Publishing USA.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Can recognize rhyming words.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several words daily.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Can recognize rhyming words.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several words daily.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Can recognize rhyming words.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole-/small-group writing activities.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several words daily.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Can recognize rhyming words.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several words daily.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Can recognize rhyming words.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several words daily.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
